txt: The shift to telecommuting / working from home will be permanent for many.
Many restaurants will permanently shift to delivery and online models with no public facing option.
We will see more shops and business parks converted to flats and housing

During the pandemic air quality improvements have been reported on, but implementation of clean air zones have been deferred. Shopping behaviours have shifted, but in ways that might hit the high street harder than the supermarkets.
Should be about equity, social justice and integration. Accessibility, re–allocation of streetspace in favor of transit, cycling and walking
If a business, office or factory was as dangerous as the highway network it would be shut down
We will encourage some remote work to stay remote, and reallocate road space to bus lanes & cycle tracks, infrastructure for bike purchases.

Better standards for cleaning, metrics to ensure that cleaning occurs, more frequent service on viable routes, and demand-response feeders.  We will likely ditch cash fares which were expensive anyway for a common platform for information, booking, payment and reporting.

Lots of access to green space locally which might not be the case for bigger cities. Likely to therefore see less street closures creating space for social distancing allowing people to be physically active
Modelling overly relies on extrapolating the present state of things and the forecasts look too like the present but more of it
Given me hope that we might actually be able to divest from flying, as air traffic has now come to a halt and the air industry is threatened.

Unfortunately there may be a loss of confidence in public transport. However, the merits of homeworking may reduce commuter pressure on public transport and car use. Also, staggered work times may be more common so public transport is used more regularly through the day
Car use is constrained more in major cities than other urban areas
I discovered during lockdown daily walks amazing area just in few min walks. The pandemic will change people perception about travelling.
Air travel is fundamentally unsustainable.

Fiscal effects probably the greatest impact. Companies will need to reevaluate revenue sources, non-profits will need to look at new ways of philanthropy. In the long-term too, I think we will see more flexibility in how we work. Many businesses have observed that employees can do their work remotely - we don't necessarily need buildings or "places to work".
Public and active Transportation have to be centered as a core element of the economic recovery.
More POC transportation experts will be tapped and listened to.
More focus on the '10 minute neighbourhood' or similar where people can walk or cycle to all their daily needs.
Opportunity to live/work closer to home and get started on the 15 minute city.
Increased supply to reduce density, encouragement of mask use during public transport, encouragement of use of off-peak services
A properly integrated transport policy (public, private & self powered) must to be driven locally to cater for the people in that place
A greater role for Active Transport within a 5km range of major employment locations - not just city centres
We need mobility management on motorways and other arterial roads.
Decision makers subconsciously favour their situation e.g. live in a detached home and drive to work, hence that is the best option for all!
Transport systems designed to respond to the places and people they connect
We will see better standards for cleaning in public transport, and better metrics to ensure that effective cleaning occurs.

When walking around the neighbourhood it is very obvious how much space is given over to cars, both for parking and driving, and how people are enjoying using that space for other activites now that there is little car transport.
The industry is overly secretive in planning and design, in result this is harming the quality of design and by extension society
Public transport will focus less on efficiency measures and more on user experience.
We need to include parking in our thinking about the 'mobility ecosystem'
Public transportation is considered more essential than I previously thought.
Despite the best efforts of authorities, politicians etc. it will be a generation before we break the psychological dependency for cars
Offices will become places to meet and interact, there will be lots of space on highways and public transport as 'peak demand' disappears
We are seeing a siginificant loss of confidence in public transport.
walk and cycle can only do so much, shared transport either bus or psv or shared cars will be the key to major changes
Dispersed urban development, the much-maligned urban sprawl) will again be sexy. Compact high-density developments will lose allure as fertile epicenter for pandemic.
Autonomous vehicles will result in a renaissance for slow energy efficient water/canal based freight
Yes, reduce commute to work times, yes, more localism but only if there is equality of access to digital infrastructure
The pandemic has exposed the fragility of most common business models supporting public transport.
AQMAs from 2002 shows that air quality isn't being taken seriously enough
I do not own a car
More cycling and walking in cities globally.

Slow transport movement. Cities heal themselves from commuter chaos, as more people choose to work remotely, work flexible hours, integrate exercise into their commute, appreciate the resilience of human-powered modes of transportation.
With more people working from home, there will be changes to the economy & land use, in terms of location of restaurants, shops etc.
Restoring confidence in using public transport will be linked to the restart and reopening of large public events (e.g. major sport events)
There has to be a big drive to improve cycling with new safe cycle routes, free cycling lessons etc.
Current edge of town development are car dependent concrete warrens and will become as fashionable as the 50s concrete towers
New ammunition for more active transportation possibilities, emphasizing secure/safe neighborhoods in addition to calmed streets.
I was thinking about selling my car, but not anymore.
Commuting will be valued based on surrounding areas AND amenities AND if it is possible to be done on sustainable modes.
Streets are the most important public space which we possess. The allocation of street space has a direct impact on our travel choices.
Using Value of Time in scheme appraisal is flawed
Don't act too quickly.  Ad hoc transport development is normally a bad thing as it lacks real forethought and integration.
Local shops will resist changes to parking or access even more vociferously
I like trains

Far fewer flights, collapse of airlines and much higher prices for long distance travel, public transport providers nationalised, return to private ownership and use, reduced congestion due to economic decline.
We travel to much, especially commuting trips. Most meetings and work can be conducted virtually or remotely.

I fear I was naive to not have seen something like this coming, a disruption that puts a pause on the push factors (congestion, gas prices, etc.), while substantially increasing the perception of risk that comes with ditching your own car in favor of shared mobility.

I am rather concerned that the upcoming economic crisis will rather worsen the current austere and efficiency-driven approaches in transport and mobility planning and not provide the necessary resources, alternatives and redundancies (staff, transport modes, tracks etc.) that we need in times like these
The end of the franchise regime and a return to a state managed and planned network.
The pandemic will lead to a large investment by local governments and transport authorities into reshaping streets as shared spaces.
The pandemic has shown that business-owned public transport is not viable. Public transport can be sustained, but at a high societal cost.
More automation vis-a-vis both the users and the operators; possible dampening effect on the use of mass public transport unless cities take pro-active measures to limit individual mobility
I expect an exodus of young families from high density living as a result of mental scars left by the cabin fever of having to cram modern work into the same space as raising children.

International flights will remain restricted after the collapse of many airlines, and those that wish to recover are encouraged to adopt more environmentally friendly vehicles such as electric propulsion and airships. This totally changes people's perception on travel, as fossil fuel powered transport becomes rapidly obsolete.

Bluntly: public transport got scary and needs to do something to reassure me; private ride sharing sounds half dead and needs to reinvent itself till COVID is gone; I was thinking about selling my car, not anymore.
Improving connectivity has been to the detriment of local communities
Shifting funding priorities and possible ripple affects from population movements away from dense city centers to lower density environments that could shift transit demand patterns.
More focus on the '10 minute neighbourhood' or similar where people can walk or cycle to all their daily needs. This is resiliency.
If we are to truly change our transport landscape for a better future, planning and funding need critical oversight that focuses on need
This will collapse airlines and international travel, and spur the move towards localism, which will have a positive impact on reduction in greenhouse emissions and the climate emergency.
Air quality, health, climate change must point to a drastic reduction of fuelled km travelled and "more complete" mixed-use integrated areas
Digital connectivity is better than physical connectivity for outcomes and VfM.
I am somewhat surprised both at how much I depended on trains / buses, and how well I can do without them when I must.
20th C design is against 100s of years of living and working. Pubs used to be in homes, we will see return of smaller local businesses
Their is a big disconnect in Active Travel mapping! Post Covid 19 we will see a massive improvement, all driven by the smart phone market..
Careful thought should be given to how future transport networks connect rural and urban communities, maximising accessibility.
Travel times have improve over the last 100 years resulting in people living further away from shops and work
Our tools and software are not good enough for consider all the options needed

The knee-jerk reaction by many people is that this pandemic shows us why density is bad and therefore we are going to have a lot of car-dependent sprawl in the future to accommodate lower density development.
If highways were built to the same standard of planing, design, and funding as cycling; I wouldn't be surprised if cars had 2% of the trips.
We travel to much- especially commuting trips. Most meetings and work can be conducted virtually or remotely.

This will worsen the current austere and efficiency-driven approaches in transport and mobility planning and not provide the necessary resources, alternatives and redundancies (staff, transport modes, tracks etc.) that we need.
We don't know if it is "rich countries build roads" or "roads build rich countries"
We'll see a return to pre-pandemic travel patterns, with marginal increases in work-from-home and bicycling offset by ongoing transit woes.
Autonomous vehicles are more likely to improve public transport first before private vehicles
Land-use and transport planning needs to be more joined up
Quantifying more externalities would make it difficult for highway schemes to have a good BCR
The economic externalities of highways are far too high
We will see the permanent closure of a lot of streets to through traffic, especially streets in and near parks and smaller residential streets.

Hopefully there will be a few more people working from home after this is over. Less impact to the roads allows for a more timely completion of outstanding upgrades. More people on bikes and scooters would also assist this and assist in a healthier population.
Things will not change as much as we would hope but some gains will be seized by proactive planners and governments local and national.
Good infrastructure is more important than any soft measures
Cars cease to be the go to option: rail and sea take their place fully as part of a network that includes local roading. Just in time becomes less JIT and more in plenty of time.
Are we all over thinking this, transport will likely stay the same?

I'm surprised and disappointed by the number of people embedded in their longstanding policy ambitions. I think it's a real constraint on a behavioural approach to user transition. If the transport and place policy can't open their own minds to new behaviours, how can they expect to hear what people are saying, much less fathom the underlying motivations and possible solutions.
Where a city/area can absorb additional car usage these maybe new areas of growth.
It is wrong for guidance to require ramp up profiles for highway schemes, and decay profiles for cycling schemes.
Traffic forecast and economic forecasts consistently over predict growth
Economic crisis in the years to come will reduce funding for public transport.

I live in an area which is relatively prosperous where the majority of residents perform well paid white collar jobs many of which can be done remotely. Patterns of employment and unemployment will be strongly correlated to the way that the pandemic measures will be experienced and will affect the impact on transport.
an interesting if perhaps optimistic view
An acknowledgement that transit service is essential to ensure essential workforce can continue working
New demand patterns may mean less public transport in morning peak, and more during daytime  Evening/night demand not coming back soon.
We will see restrictions of motor vehicles into city centers, and prioritisation of public transport and cycling.
The pandemic will launch a wave of new policies and infrastructure for urban delivery and curbside pick-up.
Rail and sea travel will take their place fully as critical components of the transport network.
Pricing single-occupant vehicle travel is the only policy that really matters. All else is tinkering around the edges.
People live closer to where they work, or they telework more. Cities focus increasingly on equitable public transport investment.
Now is the time to banish the private car from town and city centres, in favour of streets geared to walking and cycling.
We need road pricing. Cars need to pay the full cost of their impact.

Flying habits and low cost airlines may change forever. In public transport intelligent systems may take over to redefine city routes of buses based on hourly demand. This may even reshape railed transport.
Transport forecasts focused too much on the central scenario not the possible scenarios

Behavior change and consumption patterns will be forever altered; this can potentially break the status quo politicians have been stuck to and allow the opportunity to rethink systems and incorporate new methods and environmental justice/equity considerations.
Resilience and contingencies has been neglected, COIVD-19 caught the industry by surprise and without changes the next disaster will too
UK Guidance make changing the status quo in travel mode difficult
1/3rd of land-use dedicated to car parking is too much
